text: I would always suggest creating templates for people to follow - whether that’s a blog post framework with prompts for people to fill in, or interview questions to respond to. It’s much easier than just asking someone to write something, and will be easier for you to edit the results. Make sure that you structure questions/prompts in such as way as to avoid simple ‘yes’ or ‘no’ answers. Finally, if you can, meet with that person to explain what you’re looking for before you begin - in person or over Zoom.

elements.text: I would always suggest creating templates for people to follow - whether that’s a blog post framework with prompts for people to fill in, or interview questions to respond to. Finally, if you can, meet with that person to explain what you’re looking for before you begin - in person or over Zoom.

text:
You all!, I just finish reading this <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CUYDAGXKR/p1646408297939349|super-interesting thread> from <@U019SM5LH6D> about measuring the business impact of content marketing, which made me think of a different question:

*if you were given the freedom to pick _any_ metric to measure your content by, no matter how weird or outlandish it sounds, which one would you pick?* :sparkles:

elements.text: You all!, I just finish reading this
super-interesting thread
from
about measuring the business impact of content marketing, which made me think of a different question:
if you were given the freedom to pick
any
metric to measure your content by, no matter how weird or outlandish it sounds, which one would you pick?

text:
I ask because our team at Wildbit/Postmark recently chose “sparking joy” as a KPI for one of our content marketing initiatives, and after publication we basically went and looked the amount of :heart: / :joy: / :clap::skin-tone-4: emojis we received + the general ‘vibe’ of comments and replies we got.

That was it, really—it’s a bizarre KPI, but it made me feel _sooooo goood_ about the work we were doing.

What would you do?

elements.text: I ask because our team at Wildbit/Postmark recently chose “sparking joy” as a KPI for one of our content marketing initiatives, and after publication we basically went and looked the amount of

emojis we received + the general ‘vibe’ of comments and replies we got.

That was it, really—it’s a bizarre KPI, but it made me feel
sooooo goood

about the work we were doing.

What would you do?

text:
I believe this is a very good exercise for anyone creating content.

For me the metric would be a binary one (yes or no). I would really want the readers to think: "hm.. these guys know what they are talking about"

Read through that thread with <@U019SM5LH6D> as well and super interested in how other content folks are measuring business impact (something I’m working on internally as well). My 2 cents:
• *BOFU metric*: revenue
• *TOFU metric:* time on page

: revenue

text: Honestly, it may be unconventional but by the number of shares, pins, reactions, comments, and engagement on the piece of content. I feel like if people are having conversations and engaging in the content whether it be a blog with comments or social media what people are doing with the content is the most important metric of all. It just speaks to me more about what people are doing with the content.  Sure you want it to convert but it's the sharing and engaging with the content that drives people the most.

It just speaks to me more about what people are doing with the content.  Sure you want it to convert but it's the sharing and engaging with the content that drives people the most.

text: Need practical tips on interviews vs async:  I'm writing an indepth piece on how Saas marketers have implemented Jobs to Be Done research. I need to talk with  Saas marketers to get the story: 'how I did it / what were challenges  / what were the results to my marketing".  It's essential I get quotes and examples. I've reached out to some Saas folks and they prefer async and a list of questions or a form to fill instead of meeting for an interview.  I totally understand, they're busy.  I don't want to overwhelm with a mega list of questions.  Any suggestion or best practices when sending out questions.  Google form? Typeface?  Is there a max amount of questions?  Keep it short, or go in depth?  Should I gently push for an interview ?  Suggest a Loom?  Would love advice before I send anything out. Thx!    Also if you've done JTBD for marketing at your Saas, I'd love to hear from you :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I'd measure *resonance,* as in did this piece resonate with the audience? Did they mention it to a friend? Did it change the way they think about something? Did they bring it up in a convo with Sales or CS? Did they think about it at all after they closed the browser tab?

text: <@UUJBPA9K5> thank you! I'm trying to make the case that we should measure content's impact throughout the funnel, because I know that customers/prospects are engaging with our content throughout their journey. Do you have a separate Demand Gen function somewhere on your team? In our case, gated content is mainly promoted by demand gen, and the # of MQLs is heavily dependent on that promotion. Still struggling with how to distinguish the results of the content + the results of the ads. Obviously the content has a hand in the success of the ads, so it's quite intertwined...

text:
*Eye-opening* as a metric maybe? I usually love the kind of content that shares ideas and facts that were right there in front of my eyes. I just didn't see them until someone pointed them out. In a simple, easy-to-understand way. Kind of creates a ‘Eureka’ moment for me. 

Of course, crafting such content and not making it seem like you're just stating the obvious will demand some excellent writing skills.

text: Hey y'all! How do you do research for your blog target audience? for b2b it's weird because there are different people involved in the decision. I'm convinced we should target practitioners (largely female 20s and 30s) while someone else is convinced we should target decision makers (largely male 35-55). Clearly, each would result in very different content. What are y'alls thoughts on this dilemma, and any advice or resources on audience research?

elements.text: Hey y'all! How do you do research for your blog target audience? for b2b it's weird because there are different people involved in the decision. I'm convinced we should target practitioners (largely female 20s and 30s) while someone else is convinced we should target decision makers (largely male 35-55). Clearly, each would result in very different content. What are y'alls thoughts on this dilemma, and any advice or resources on audience research?

text: <@U019SM5LH6D> Yep, we have a separate Demand Gen squad on the Marketing team. We do our own promotion of gated content by email and organic social, but we also partner with Demand Gen to distribute content thru paid ads.

elements.text: Yep, we have a separate Demand Gen squad on the Marketing team. We do our own promotion of gated content by email and organic social, but we also partner with Demand Gen to distribute content thru paid ads.

text:
Hey Olivia!

If you're in SaaS/PLG, it's likely the practitioners who be the ones who need to discover you, so your SEO-type content should be targeted to them and their jobs to be done.

But you're right, some products/services are bought by teams, so you may also need a smattering of thought leadership-y stuff for the decision-makers.

Rather than focusing on their demographics, I'd just address what goals each role has. What problems are you solving for them, etc.  (e.g. practitioners may want to do X more efficiently, and their bosses may want to be able to monitor them more easily).

You may be able to cover both in one fell swoop, or you may need targeted content for each.

Hope that helps a lil' bit!

elements.text:
Hey Olivia!

If you're in SaaS/PLG, it's likely the practitioners who be the ones who need to discover you, so your SEO-type content should be targeted to them and their jobs to be done.

But you're right, some products/services are bought by teams, so you may also need a smattering of thought leadership-y stuff for the decision-makers.

Rather than focusing on their demographics, I'd just address what goals each role has. What problems are you solving for them, etc.  (e.g. practitioners may want to do X more efficiently, and their bosses may want to be able to monitor them more easily).

You may be able to cover both in one fell swoop, or you may need targeted content for each.

Hope that helps a lil' bit!

text: I’m a big fan of a half hour with some time to answer questions at the end!

elements.text: I’m a big fan of a half hour with some time to answer questions at the end!

text: Agree with Eric! I’m a freelance B2B tech writer, and for most of my clients, the SEO content we produce is targeted at practitioners who may be searching for solutions to specific problems. Then, thought leadership content is directed towards the decision-maker that they may find when checking out the company website or social, ideally after a practitioner surfaces the brand. For example, for a company that has a data quality solution for data engineers, I write a lot of blog posts about data testing, data monitoring, solving for data quality, etc. Then some of the thought leadership posts may be about how to build a data tech stack, building data trust within an organization, etc. Very approximate examples but that’s one approach that has worked for my clients.

elements.text: Agree with Eric! I’m a freelance B2B tech writer, and for most of my clients, the SEO content we produce is targeted at practitioners who may be searching for solutions to specific problems. Then, thought leadership content is directed towards the decision-maker that they may find when checking out the company website or social, ideally after a practitioner surfaces the brand. For example, for a company that has a data quality solution for data engineers, I write a lot of blog posts about data testing, data monitoring, solving for data quality, etc. Then some of the thought leadership posts may be about how to build a data tech stack, building data trust within an organization, etc. Very approximate examples but that’s one approach that has worked for my clients.

text: <@UUJBPA9K5> then do you co-own "New MQLs from gates" with Demand Gen?

elements.text: then do you co-own "New MQLs from gates" with Demand Gen?

text: I guess you could say it's shared. Demand gen reports on new MQLs from paid ads, and we report on new MQLs from content gates overall. We're all working towards the same overall Marketing targets, so we don't worry so much about who owns what.

elements.text: I guess you could say it's shared. Demand gen reports on new MQLs from paid ads, and we report on new MQLs from content gates overall. We're all working towards the same overall Marketing targets, so we don't worry so much about who owns what.

text:
I’m a freelance B2B SaaS writer and work with the SaaS Nordic team and in my experience B2B writing that directly addresses a pain point always trumps everything else.

What has made my writing better is that instead of saying-

 ‘Customer Data guide for marketers’ (with a tone of authority) 

saying -
‘What is the number 1 problems marketers are facing while handling customer data?’ (Tone of helpfulness) has been a game changer for me. 

Building the entire blog in a flow chart of logically flowing pain points creates a very valuable read because it addresses the immediate next question your reader has. 

Here is the ebook I use most often —
It highlights the pain points and key challenges of all C-Suite Execs. 

<https://f.hubspotusercontent00.net/hubfs/541808/Sales%20Ebooks/Selling%20to%20the%20C-level.pdf?hsCtaTracking=e7f0c934-5632-4354-a12e-ba71cf0cacdf%7C8a8b8b68-1dfa-4b44-9e35-a73cc3aa1b25|https://f.hubspotusercontent00.net/hubfs/541808/Sales%20Ebooks/Selling%20to%20the%20C-level.pdf?hsCtaTracking=e7f0c934-5632-4354-a12e-ba71cf0cacdf%7C8a8b8b68-1dfa-4b44-9e35-a73cc3aa1b25>

2. Filling our a HARO, Help a B2B Writer, and Qwoted to find more niche pain points and then sorting them out based on the responders’ position in a company.

For example, if I’m writing a blog on ‘must have sales reports’ targeted to sales managers I will filter my Haro responses to those which come from sales managers, Chief Sales Officers and such.

Instead of asking a direct question (which will get a generic response) like ‘what is a must have sales report?’, it’s better to ask ‘what is your biggest challenge while navigating sales assessment?’ and then select the report that adresses that challenge.
